questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Nasal infections are the most common cause of sinusitis since sinus mucosa is a continuation of nasal mucosa and infections from the nose can travel directly by continuity or by way of submucosal lymphatics.
The most common cause of acute sinusitis is viral rhinitis followed by bacterial invasion.

Other causes:

  • Dental infections cause maxillary sinus infections.
  • Trauma
  • Swimming and diving.

questions.text: Identify the most common sinus involved in sinusitis in adults.
questions.solution:
The structure marked 4 is the maxillary sinus and is the most common sinus involved in acute sinusitis in adults. 

Order of frequency of sinuses involved in acute sinusitis in adults is maxillary > ethmoid > frontal > sphenoid.

questions.text: A patient with sinusitis is least likely to present with which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
Diplopia is least likely to be seen in sinusitis.

Patients with sinusitis typically present with a dull throbbing headache which worsens on moving the head or bending forward, nasal discharge and blockage, & constitutional symptoms like fever, general malaise and bodyache.

Option A: Occipital headache can be seen in sphenoid sinusitis.

Option B: Eyelid edema can be seen in frontal and ethmoidal sinusitis.

Option D: Post-nasal drip and nasal discharge is a common finding in sinusitis.

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

Symptoms of maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

Symptoms of frontal sinusitis:

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Edema of the upper eyelid

Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis:

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose and deep to the eye that is aggravated by the movements of the eyeball
  • Edema of both eyelids,
  • Nasal discharge

Symptoms of sphenoid sinusitis:

  • Headache localized to occiput or vertex
  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: A 28-year-old IT professional with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection has a headache that worsens during office hours. The headache comes upon waking, tends to be at its worst by about midday and improves as the day progresses. This characteristic periodicity is seen in?
questions.solution:
Headache in frontal sinusitis shows characteristic periodicity, i.e. comes upon waking, gradually increases, reaches its peak by about midday, and then starts subsiding. It is also called office headache because of its presence only during office hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common sinusitis in children?
questions.solution:
The ethmoid sinus is the most common sinus involved in pediatric sinusitis.

It usually occurs when the infection spreads through the lamina papyracea.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child diagnosed with sphenoid sinusitis was brought to the hospital with complaints of a fever and headache. The headache would most likely be localised to?
questions.solution:
Headache in sphenoid sinusitis is localized to occiput or vertex.
Frontal headache is seen in maxillary and frontal sinusitis. Headache in frontal sinusitis has characteristic periodicity.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of recurrent episodes of sinusitis for two years presented with complaints of a dull aching pain over his cheek, persistent nasal obstruction which worsens at night and an urge to constantly clear his throat. Which of the following anterior rhinoscopy findings is pathognomonic of the condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of chronic maxillary sinusitis. Mucoid or mucopurulent discharge in the middle meatus seen on anterior rhinoscopy is a pathognomonic finding in chronic maxillary sinusitis.

Other signs include mucosal edema primarily in the middle meatus as well as polyps. Clinically, patients present with nasal blockage, congestion, postnasal drip, reduced olfaction, and facial pain or pressure. On CT, mucosal changes within the osteomeatal complex and sinuses may be seen.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient presented with fever, headache and, hawking sensation. Suspecting severe sinusitis, you order an X-ray of the PNS. Which view would be best in capturing all the paranasal sinuses in a single film?
questions.solution:
The lateral view shows all the paranasal sinuses in a single film.

The lateral side of the skull lies against the film, and an X-ray beam is projected perpendicular to the other side.

Structures seen are:

  • Anterior and posterior extent of the sphenoid, frontal sinus
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Sella turcica
  • Alveolar process
  • Condyle and neck of the mandible.

Note: Though all the abnormalities and diagnoses of Paranasal sinuses cannot be concluded through the lateral view alone, the lateral view radiographically covers all the sinuses in the same view. 

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: A patient with deviated nasal septum presents with a headache that starts upon waking and reaches its peak by about midday. On examination, she has upper eyelid oedema and tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus. Which of the following X-ray views is preferred to best evaluate the sinus involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of frontal sinusitis. The best view for evaluating the frontal sinus is Caldwell's view.

It is also known as occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: Which of the following is used to make a definitive diagnosis of sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Diagnostic nasal endoscopy findings are used to confirm the diagnosis of sinusitis.

Indications of diagnostic nasal endoscopy:

  • To diagnose any disease of the nose and PNS
  • To find the source of bleeding in epistaxis
  • To assess response to medical or surgical treatment of the nose and PNS disease
  • To take a precise biopsy from the nose and nasopharynx

questions.text: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Soft palate paralysis is not a known complication of sinusitis.

Complications of paranasal sinus infection:

  • Local
    • Mucocele/Mucopyocele
    • Mucous retention cyst
    • Osteomyelitis - Frontal bone (more common), maxilla
  • Orbital
    • Preseptal inflammatory oedema of lids
    • Subperiosteal abscess
    • Orbital cellulitis
    • Orbital abscess
    • Superior orbital fissure syndrome
    • Orbital apex syndrome
  • Intracranial
    • Meningitis
    • Extradural abscess
    • Subdural abscess
    • Brain abscess
    • Cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • Descending infections
  • Focal infections

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication following acute rhinosinusitis?
questions.solution:
Orbital cellulitis is the most common complication following acute rhinosinusitis.

Complications of acute rhinosinusitis are typically classified as orbital (60–75 per cent), intracranial (15–20 per cent) and osseous (5–10 per cent), and local and descending infections.

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady presents with pain and swelling around the left upper eyelid region, diplopia and a headache. She gives a history of recurrent episodes of rhinosinusitis in the past. On examination, there is a downward, and outward deviation of the eyeball & the most prominent part of the swelling has a punctum with a mucopurulent discharge, just above the upper eyelid. Which of the following sinuses is most commonly involved in this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and findings are suggestive of a mucocele secondary to frontal sinusitis. The frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele formation.

The sinuses commonly affected by mucocele in the order of frequency are the frontal>ethmoidal>maxillary>sphenoid

The image given below shows a coronal MRI demonstrating a frontal mucocele and an orbital cystic mass.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about mucoceles?

choices.text: Frontal sinus is most commonly involved
Presents as a cystic swelling in the superomedial quadrant
Eyeball is pushed downwards, forwards and medially

questions.solution:
Eyeballs are pushed downwards, forwards and laterally.

Option A: Frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele.

Option B: It presents as a cystic swelling in the superomedial quadrant of orbit.

Option D: Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of the frontal sinus into the middle meatus.

questions.text: A young man was referred to the maxillofacial surgeon with complaints of pain and tenderness over the left cheek, inability to move the left eye, and numbness over the left forehead. He gave a history of chronic sinusitis for two years. Superior orbital fissure syndrome was suspected. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The maxillary division of trigeminal nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure and thus, is the least likely nerve to be involved in this condition.

Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by the compression of cranial nerves III, IV, VI, and ophthalmic division of V. The superior orbital fissure lies between the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid. The structures passing through include cranial nerves III, IV, VI, the ophthalmic branch of V, and the superior ophthalmic vein.

Orbital apex syndrome is superior orbital fissure syndrome with additional involvement of optic nerve and maxillary division of trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true?

choices.text: Osteomyelitis of maxilla is more common in children
Osteomyelitis of frontal bone is more common in adults
Ethmoidal sinusitis spreads through lamina papyracea
Pott’s puffy tumor is related to osteomyelitis of maxilla

questions.solution:
Pott's puffy tumor refers to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone with the development of a subperiosteal abscess manifesting as a puffy swelling on the forehead or scalp. It usually occurs as a complication of frontal sinusitis.

Option A: Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is more often seen in infants and children than adults because of the presence of spongy bone in the anterior wall of the maxilla.

Option B: Osteomyelitis of frontal bone is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.

Option C: Ethmoidal sinusitis spreads through lamina papyracea

questions.text: A middle-aged patient with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections presents with diplopia and protrusion of the left eyeball. Inflammation of which of the following paranasal sinuses would most likely lead to this complication?
questions.solution: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of orbital complications secondary to sinusitis. The orbit and its contents are closely related to the ethmoid, frontal, and maxillary sinuses, but most of the complications, however, follow infection of ethmoids as they are separated from the orbit only by a thin lamina of bone called lamina papyracea.

questions.text: A procedure that involves puncturing and irrigating the sinus is planned for a patient with a history of chronic sinusitis. For which of the following paranasal sinuses is this procedure performed?
questions.solution:
Proof puncture or antral lavage involves puncturing the medial wall of maxillary sinus in the region of inferior meatus to allow for irrigation and drainage of the sinus.

It is called proof puncture, as the presence of an infection can be proven during the procedure.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is antral lavage not indicated?
questions.solution:
In acute maxillary sinusitis, antral lavage is actually contraindicated for the risk of osteomyelitis.

Antral lavage is usually done therapeutically to remove pus and diagnostically for confirmation of chronic maxillary sinusitis. It can also be done to collect the specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

questions.text: While performing a therapeutic antral lavage of the maxillary sinus, the patient developed a fatal complication. He stopped breathing, the colour of his face became ashen grey, and the pupils became dilated. Attempts to resuscitate the patient were futile, and he was declared dead after 20 minutes. Which of the following could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Air embolism is a rare but fatal complication that can occur during antral lavage through the veins that are damaged during the puncture.

This complication can be prevented by avoiding the insufflation of air into the antrum after lavage.

questions.text: Which of the following sinuses is accessed via the Caldwell-Luc approach?
questions.solution: Caldwell–Luc operation is a surgery where the maxillary antrum is opened through canine fossa by sublabial approach and pathology inside the antrum dealt with.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is pierced while creating a nasoantral window in Caldwell Luc operation?
questions.solution: Nasoantral window of <1.5cm in diameter is created through the inferior meatus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of Caldwell Luc operation?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of Caldwell Luc operation is infraorbital nerve injury.

Paraesthesia due to damage of the infraorbital nerve may be temporary or permanent and is reported in 21% of cases.

questions.text: What does FESS stand for?
questions.solution:
FESS stands for Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery.

FESS is a minimally invasive procedure that uses nasal endoscopes to enlarge the nasal drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses to improve sinus ventilation and allow access to topical medications.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS).

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball
  • Nasal polyps
  • Mucocele 
  • Control of epistaxis 
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Barotrauma sinusitis (pain in the face during descent in aircraft or descent whilst scuba diving)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Acute rhinosinusitis with epidural abscess is a contraindication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery.

The endoscopic approach is contraindicated in the presence of an intracranial complication of acute infection such as:

  • Meningitis
  • Subperiosteal abscess
  • Epidural abscess
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • Any visual loss 

Note: Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis, allergic fungal sinusitis with mycetoma and repair of cerebrospinal fluid leak.

questions.text: Which of the following structures cannot be accessed by performing an endoscopic nasal surgery?
questions.solution:
Cerebellum cannot be accessed by performing endoscopic nasal surgery.

Apart from the nose and paranasal sinuses, endoscopic surgery can be used to access the orbit, optic nerve, lacrimal sac, and pituitary gland.

Indications of advanced nasal endoscopic techniques:

  • Removal of benign tumors, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas
  • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy
  • Repair of CSF leak
  • Pituitary surgery
  • Optic nerve decompression
  • Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease
  • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery)
  • Choanal atresia

questions.text: A 45-year-old-man with a history of chronic sinusitis unresponsive to medications is planned for functional endoscopic sinus surgery. Which of the following is the first step in the procedure?
questions.solution: Uncinectomy where uncinate process is incised with sickle knife and removed with Blakesley forceps is the first definitive surgical step in FESS.

questions.text: You are a third-year ENT resident performing a functional endoscopic sinus surgery on a patient diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. During the procedure, the lateral wall of the infundibulum is punctured adjacent to the maxillary sinus ostium. Why is this step done?
questions.solution: Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in FESS and it is done to approach the middle meatus.

questions.text: Water’s view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses?
questions.solution:
Water’s view is used to best visualize the maxillary sinus. Frontal and ethmoidal sinuses can also be visualized. Sphenoid sinus can be seen in Water's view with open mouth.

It is also known as the occipitomental view. The X-ray beam is angled at 37°-45° to the orbitomeatal line. 

The recommended imaging views for different sinuses are as follows:

  • Ethmoidal sinus: Rheese's view
  • Frontal sinus: Caldwell's view
  • Sphenoid sinus: Hirtz view

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: The radiograph shown below is done for better assessment of the frontal sinus. What is the common name of this view?
questions.solution:
The frontal sinus is best seen in Caldwell's view (occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position).

The structures seen in Caldwell's view include:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of the orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The nose and forehead are touching the X-ray film and the X-ray beam is projected 15 degrees caudally in Caldwell's view.

Other options:

Option A: Water's view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view where an X-ray beam is angled at 45 degrees to the orbitomeatal line. Structures seen are the maxillary sinus (best seen), sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth), frontal sinus, zygoma, zygomatic arch, nasal bone, and infratemporal fossa. 

Option C: Pierre's view is the occipitomental with an open mouth. It helps in visualizing the sphenoid sinus as well, in addition to the sinuses that can be seen in water's view.

Option D: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen are the petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum, internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
